My understanding is that the creation of this channel was discussed at the last fabric maintainers meeting. Unfortunately I was not able to attend so feel free to fill me in on any missed details

We should use this channel to get together once per week (Wednesday at 10am EDT?) and address at least 5 outstanding PRs. For each PR we should either merge, close, or comment. Hopefully this will help unstick some PRs and make sure they’re not in limbo for too long
For our first set, I’d like to nominate 1719, 1721, and 1722 for discussion. Let me know if there are any other you’d like to put on the list for consideration

Thanks <@U0KM61BCP> for that note; I have to agree, there are so many slack channels here that it can be confusing for new developers to come up to speed on what's happening where.  I would urge you not to have more and more slack channels for particular functions, and not to use slack channels for making project decisions.  The mailing lists are designed for this, are real-time, and afford participation by those who can't all be at the same place at the same time.  I appreciate the urgency to address and close outstanding PRs, that's great, but it shouldn't have to wait for a particular hour of the week.

e.g. I would have taken <@U0MT4CBHB> 's post yesterday and PR by PR, if it covered parts of the code I'm familiar with, I would have either commented and given it support or criticism.  A separate thread per PR would be even better, as that would make for easier threading in the archives and in our mail clients.
<@U0ULK2JPP|muralisr> has joined the channel
Also, there is no graceful cross-posting tool between Slack and mailing lists, because the mode of communication is so different between them.

All good IMHO to use Slack as a tool to help explore an issue, understand a defect or architecture better, help each other through the code.  But anything decisional should be done on the lists, and presume that there are lots more smart people outside the room and outside the time zone who would have something valuable to contribute.
<@U0MSG4RL7|dmurik> has joined the channel

One last thing - I did see that there is commentary on each PR within the comments on it - I think that's great!  Maybe what's needed is some way to get a signal from enough of a critical mass of developers to go forward with the merge; and in the case of Tamas's code, accept the pull request himself.  On Apache in the early days we tended to use "three +1's, and no vetos", meaning so long as you could point to support from three other people (ideally not co-workers but we can roll with that for now) and no other developer stepping up to object to the change, then you could proceed to commit the change.  Perhaps that would be enough to do it no.

I think the chaincode events is useful - we will have to add things like security and access control ( to control who can get what events etc) but it provides some alternate paths to make design of applications easier

<@U0MT4CBHB> persistence of events is a requirement and has been discussed, but as i said, the implementation of the persistence is a hack at this point since we don’t want to change the API and the data causing backward compatibiilty issues
<@U0KN2SSKE>: same question to you. How do events fit with an architecture where endorsers execute chaincode and and content is opaque for others?
How do you address privacy and conflict of this new data structure in addition to worldstate and blockchain
whom would you think interest in the custom events?
but before you start tell me the use case the requirement was derived from
Endorsers execute chaincode and produce world state.
Endorses execute chaincode and produce events
why would events mean anything to other than endorser?
the matter of state or events is pretty synonymous from the PoV of who can see what and how opaque it is
why would you want to store them, why replay?
so you are really asking a question about any value / state stored in general
my ansewr to _events fit with an architecture where endorsers execute chaincode and and content is opaque for others_ would be same way any state would fit the architecture
in fact, come to that, PR #1754 would have the same issue wouldn’t it ?
Events are generated by chaincode execution right?
except that it ONLY posts “chaincode execution failed” and is not even store on state ?
so they are of interest for those submitting the transaction. All other do not even know what events mean.
ie, purely ephemera;
the applications are the ones interest in the appropriate events that they are authorized to listen to
it is of interest for whoever is allowed and authorized
right

<@U0KN2SSKE>: what is for everyone is on blockchain. events are only for those executing the chaincode. if you make events available for more you leak privacy or add junk to all other's infrastructure.
the way I look at it is - and this is the reason why we stored it persistently - the same holds for “events” . as well
just as a state is allowed for anyone who can view it, so can events
events provide just an alternate means for wiring applications. This is why we wanted to make sure they are NOT ephemeral

If I'd follow your argument that events are like states then I'd ask why you need both. An application can listen to blockchain and observe state changes. It can imply events for its own upstream needs if needs to. For me you introduced yet another cathegory of shared data for no good reason. with that increased complexity, vulnerability and hurt performance. what we should build here is a high performance bare bone modular blockchain and not what we could imagine being useful.

I don’t know about complexity, vulnerability and perforamnce.. to take performance alone, if I want to get the same information from state (say via query) I’d have to poll for the data (sometimes multiple times to see “if state changed”)… my point is the event approach has its place

We should only care of performance that is within the scope of the project and include support for high level optimisation after this is justified with a use case and has sufficient community pressure behind it.
I am afraid of building a swiss knife while we need a corkscrew
well, I didn’t bring up performance … I only pointed out that I don’t see how it hurts it
as I see it, events are a critical component of building compositions specifically to allow more efficient state discrimination
state is what matters, yes, but events are a view into state transitions
without them, your only options are monolithic applications or polling, neither of which are particularly great solutions in many use cases

just because an external observer may, in certain circumstances, be privy to blockchain level events such as the creation of blocks, the committing of transactions, or the mutation of state, doesn’t mean they are necessarily able to reason about what those events mean in very specific ways
custom events allow a chaincode application to distill internal schema to external schema in an application specific way
in short: i think they are a very useful abstraction

<@U0KPFAZNF>

Could you elaborate why state and blockchain is not sufficient?
Ok, so you have a chaincode application, and it has some state that can be mutated with an invoke() iff enough VPs agree that it is valid, right?
ok
that “state” is some schema modeled on top of a kv-store that the chaincode manages, right?
yes, I assume its the 'world state' of fabric a kv store, right
yes, but I actually hate the term: i prefer to think of them as merkel roots of each chaincode app, but sure
there are some number of kv entries that change in response to an accepted transaction, the mechanics/semantics dont matter much at this level
one problem is, to an outside observer, thats exactly what it looks like
a transaction goes in, and some delta to world state comes out
so, anyone that would like to derive meaning from that transform would need a deep understanding of the schema that governed all deltas leading to that point
the transform is recorded with invoke transactions.
understood, but that isnt the problem
i dont need to know that the transform happened, I need to know what the transform _means_
for instance, "did someone just deposit funds in my wallet?" as oppposed to “did the asset manager just mutate rows [x y z a b c m n o]?"
so, the event mechanism allows a chaincode app to attach semantic meaning to the operations that, really, only it understands to begin with
You want the events to translate invokes into a lower granularity actions. I think it is not the job of the framework to solve for that.
why not?
because keep it stupid simple
once we prove that that works we can add luxuriy featiures
it sounds like that is exactly what you want the framework to do, otherwise you have no other means to reason about the transaction
this isnt luxury, I don’t think you can build much utility without it
at least, not for a class of use cases I care about
If you can not reason about invokes than they are probably ill-designed.
i disagree
you can always reason about the invokes without events, but if you have operations that are predicated on invokes you would be left to poll, which is not good
events can be recreated with execution of chain code right? So why persist them?
for instance, say I have a compositional contract that reacts in response to payment
if that is your only way to reason about invokes, then execute.
oh, well persistence is another matter
I am all about persistence
i dont have a strong opinion on whether events need to be persistent or not…ephemeral is probably fine for my use cases too
It is fine to create an event and return as a feedback from validation
What I disagree with is perisistent events anotther shared data
the persistence discussion was something I wasnt involved in

<@U113EGLBE|nkunkel> has joined the channel

The blockchain is an infrastructure to distribute transactions and any node can subscribe to them. You now imply to need a lower granularity. Is it really the job of this infrastructure to help you there or are your transactions not defined at the right granularity?

<@U0MT4CBHB> there is the blockchain network, and then there are ancillary services that might want to subscribe to information about what is going on with the blockchain. I suspect that <@U0KPFAZNF> is referring to the need to get information via events that reflect what is going on
<@U0MT4CBHB>: they seem perfectly defined to me, constrained by my competence as an architect :wink:
but I think its sound
Yes, but whatever is going on is implied by transactions and distribution of them is exactly the job we build an infrastructure for.
you are then suggesting that the information implied by transactions is interesting only to the peer nodes?

<@U0MT4CBHB>: the problem I think people run into is its easy to say “do this function somewhere else” but that becomes a less tenable proposal when you consider the reasons people need/want to run on a blockchain
Yes. that is the job of the blockchain distribute transactions and define their order. everything else is optimisation or sugar on top.
and I also do not think the notion of events is particularly onerous nor non-sensical to include in the framework

I disagree, there are plenty of solutions that can do strongly ordered replication
I am fine with generating events and returning them to submitter. Just not create another class of shared data.
<@U0MT4CBHB> yes, and there we agree - but something needs to emit them… I agree that it is rather silly that we don’t just leverage 0mq or kafka
blockchain, to me, is about having an agreement protocol for mutation policy
and some mutations are composible
i need the event mechanism to do that, otherwise I have to poll or trust an external component

state mutation is only implied by set sequence of immutable transaction. shared persistent state is only an optimisation, not the core of the technology. See Bitcoin. It has an implied state (the UTXO) but only replicates ordered sequence of transactions. Similarly Hyperledgers kv state is only an optimisation that could be recomputed through reexecuting all transaction in the order set by consensus. Events you ask for could be recreated in the same process. The point is the more 'optimisations' you introduce on top of the core function of storing ordered immutable transactions the more complex the system will be. Chances are it will be the less stable and secure.
Theres always a complexity line, but I dont think this crosses it
and <@U0KM61BCP>, I dont disagree with the 0mq observation…im likely just going to bridge SDK to 0mq anyway
so, if the peers surfaced a native 0mq subscription point, thats probably awesome from my perspective
but id have to look into it deeper to see if that makes sense in the context of a potentially hostile network
<@U0KPFAZNF>: I was thinking we could use a pluggable approach but yes
yeah, thats the way to go

I think you underestimate how fiercely this infrastructure will be attacked and what value it will have to protect. There is no better strategy to deal with that than having respect toward the problem and assume that implications of features are much bigger than you first think. I'd hope the DAO was opening eyes.

well, one of my problems was that we didnt have events, so we asked for them….now, the community doesn’t have to agree to their importance but to say its a lack of respect to the problem is not really understanding where we are coming from.  The way I see it, it will be difficult to compose applications that will be meaningful to the purpose of blockchain without them.  I guess we should flip it around:  what is the problem you think these events are going to cause?

I do not want persistent failure events as they create obvious DoS. I do not want persistent ok events as they are recomputable by reexecuting transactions for those who can read the transactions generated them and those who cant should not get ok events as they would either leak privacy or be just additional garbage on disk.
and in general every additional line of code is additional risk.
ok, but I think we are in agreement that persistence is uninteresting (to me), and I am not even talking about general events like confirm/reject, but custom events that a chaincode app can define
(though I am interested in txn confirmations too)
but that is a different use case
you can get custom events returned by submitting peer without persistence, this is what i suggest.
yes, dropping persistence is totally fine by me
thats all I argue for...
I dont see it as as submitting peer constraint though
I think all VPs the execute the txn will compute the event set
so, a subscriber should be able to listen elsewhere

submitting peer either execute chaincode and therefore has events or gets events from endorsing peers. if you want events forwarded to other then submitting peers then please use some message bus but not the fabric.
(maybe this is why some are pushing for persistence, so then the E’ set travels to all?
ok, i see, you are using the endorsing nomenclature
yes, thats fine
I assume we are moving toward Marko's new consensu protocol proposal
the main criteria is that for a given function f() with state S and message M, it might generate [S’, []E] = f(S, M)
where E is the set of events emitted
as long as the validation process agree to [S’ []E], and E is released at the same time S’ is accepted, I am happy
if that is a function orchestrated by the submitting peer, or persisted in the ledger, or whatever, I dont really care
I do care that it should not be persisted on ledger, so we save one shared dataset, otherwise on the same page with you.
ok
To be precise: I mean []E should not be stored
understood, and that is fine by me as long as it works
great
I do not need any kind of notion of replay of the event, as I can make reconciliation queries to cover that case
to me, that seems like one of the major drivers of persisting it
the part I guess I would need to study more is, if [S’ []E] could be considered the deterministic output, does that mean it needs to be considered part of the world state?
that I dont know
maybe its part of the hash but the event itself doesnt need to persist
You can hash []E into S' yourself in chaincode,  if you have that requirement.
how would that work?
(hash(S’) is normally done outside the chaincode by the framework
You can have a key in S' that is hash([]E)
maybe the event doesnt need to be part of the hash
yeah, you could probably do something like that
it probably has little meaning to do it at any level, though
the event, unless correlated in a strong-read fashion, should not be trusted outright but rather treated as a trigger to consult the chain
so either via explicit hash(E) or indirect in hash(S’), it might not matter
Actually you could add a key="Events" with value=[]E  in f
yeah, but you technically only need to mention the events you are emitting _right now_ so you’d want to delete that table every time
otherwise it would grow without bound (though perhaps that is the desired effect)
anyway, there are options
i need to give it more thought, but I think we can just let the event emit
it has no more authority than a system level event, like txn-confirmed
yes, a peer sent it, but does the network agree?
to put it another way, we could try to get consensus on the event ….
oh, i just thought of something
maybe that is the magic
so, for a given transaction, you have the [S’ []E] = f(S, M)
The network agrees on valid transactions and their order. Everything else is only implied. Everything else you add as optimisation is only at risk to be out of sync with that truth.
we then shop the [S’ []E] around for consensus
if we have it, S’ (or the MVCC delta of it, at least) goes in the ledger, and []E goes on the network
both of which could carry a commit-certificate on their own, in theory
so, the event could actually carry endorser signatures, if we wanted
yes thats I am saying...
ok, i like that
slight correction we shop for endorsement of [S' []E] not consensus
yes yes, i need to get the new lingo down :wink:
i think this works for me
good. please add your conclusion to the PR
ok
this is 1719?
yes, i have to get some sleep. thanks a lot
I am on CET timezone
ah, good night
bye

just read the recent exchanges…. want to make sure I understood. Chaincode can generate event to be sent out as long as we don’t persist. ie, Just like state, it can be created in a transaction. Just like state, it has to be somehow be part of endorsement to be agreed upon. But unlike state it cannot be persisted. So in future, if we want to know what was endorsed, we can only look at the state value and not the events. Don’t we want to keep around everything that was endorsed upon ?
yes, the persistence is a hack admittedly… I think we are all in agreement (well, those of us here)

<@U0KM61BCP> persistence was stored in nonhashdata in the current consensus model (in that sense a hack) but the idea was we could move it to be part of state in the next consensus model so it can be properly endorsed upon.

what was done was recognize that this was post-consensus and deliberately place events in nonhashdata to call out clearly that was not hashed upon (as opposed to storieng elsewhere) so we can fix it correctly when we move to the new model
have followed all the conversation here so far, another +1 for non-persisting the events
thinking about things some more, I am not sure that the class of events generated by chaincode can _not_ be part of the block somehow
I agree things like txn/block status are peer local and in no way belong in the persistence layer
but, for chaincode events, it seems that not including them in the block leaves the system ripe for excluding all except the voting endorsers to know about the event
but perhaps there is a better solution?
I actually am ok if only endorsers are capable of detecting/disseminating events, as that seems like the right scope from a privilege perspecptive
(IOW, i am not worried about non-endoring validators missing the signal to transmit the event)

but, say I had 10 endorsers but only 7 were involved in actively endorsing a transaction because the other three were slower, would someone subscribed to one of the slow endorsers just not find out about the event?
it seems like if, minimally hash([S’ E]) were on the block, then a slow node could use something like state transfer to recover E and send it as it learns about a committed block
is there another way that doesnt involve block state?
to put it another way, it seems like “E” is very much akin to “just another output” of the process
I am not sure that audit-ability of E is important, but having the messages have a semblance of reliability is probably important
there might be other ways to achieve that
I personally think E should be treated with the same confidentiality scope as S, which is why I am fine with subscriptions only working within the set of VPs that are endorsers for the event source
<@U0ULK2JPP>: <@U0MT4CBHB> thoughts?
yes. It was one of the reasons I opposed persistent E as it will potentially leak privacy if not handled the same as S
I agree it should be scoped identically
scoped/handled identically
e.g. if S is encrypted, E is encrypted the same, etc
at least w.r.t. the block data
the event itself probably wouldnt be encrypted or at least, not in the same way…just as a query response wouldnt be encrypted per se
we could think of events as special variant of  query, actually

<@U0KPFAZNF>: <@U0MT4CBHB> Agree that Chaincode events E have to play by the same rules as state data S. And this goes not only for persistence but also security treatment. Other “system” events such as block events can be treated differently.
agree
are there block events too? what are they and for what ?
a “block” event is sent out when a block is committed successfully. Equivalent to user polling for the block

<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2987> is ready for +2 reviews
for pruning ?
savepoint is what ensures that statedatabase and filebased blockchain are consistent
if the peer crashes, upon startup we look at last state database savepoint and replay the file based blockstorage content up until current height
the recovery logic is being done in <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2833/>
got it… I’d have thought that was already there in some form for leveldb (and previously rocksdb) no ?
the whole ledger data architecture is new for v1.  we have raw file storage for blockchain, and leveldb for state database.  we haven’t yet done the guaranteed sync upon crash until these changesets.

in an ideal world all the data would be in one place.  in a less ideal world there would be two-phase commit transactions.  in our real world we have to do the dirty work to ensure they stay in sync :slightly_smiling_face:

text: and/or for platform specific implementations...
I know, I know, some Golang devs are breaking this rule in some places...
I object to the word "reserved" I guess. But I'll note that all of my mock files will eventually move to the `mocks` package in orderer, so this issue will resolve itself.
But in general, the idea is that the `packages` what matters (more than files. And indeed, using subdirectories help “componentize” these much better.

(Yes, that’s why I have prefixed with “Well, it’s a strange one” :wink:… it is not enforced everywhere, but I find it helpful to have more “self-contained” services that live side by side happily :wink:. Maybe it’s the holiday atmosphere, I don’t know ;-))

<@U0PB67X4K> right, in the orderer case (“I’ve done everything and now to serve and block”) we do not want to spin off a goroutine…. better write to the common denom as you have
exposing that  “spin off and get notified “ pattern would serve to suggest that loosely coupling design to users of your server… but we can always do that later

In general, it is easier (for me) to work with a protocol. That is, just like the non-author sign-off, for example to “verify that a commit message reflects the change set, etc.”

In this case, it’s relatively “academic”, as I have already approved it the second I learned that the commit message accurately describes the CR, but in general, I just find it easier to work with a “general” deterministic guideline. Even though in some cases, it requires an extra CI cycle or two…. hope you’d appreciate that on average, it makes sense.

<@U10Q62R8X> so the procedure i have in mind goes like this:
- admin logs in to app node and does whatever is needed to enroll the node with CA, which generates the private key (and saved somewhere in the file system, hsm is a different matter so let’s assume this is all software managed) for the device and have the cert signed by whatever the CA
- now somehow the app needs to get the SDK to use the private key and cert
- find them and export to PEM files and put them into the standard “MSP config dir” structure
- SDK is pointed to it and will be able to load it in
in the above procedure, private key never leaves the device where it’s generated

muralisr: Nothing, the "make peer connect" is just a description. In practice, all I do there is make the discovery layer "know about" an anchor peer, and initialize it as a dead peer (in the eyes of the peer that join channel was called upon). This makes the gossip "want to connect to it".

It'll then try to connect to the anchor peer until it succeeds.
